data.title: Trip planner for multiple stops
data.meta_description: How to easily plan your route between house sits or travel stops with route planning app Rome2Rio. Here's our review.
data.meta_site_name: House Sitting Magazine - The place to discover house sitting
data.text:
Get from A to B anywhere in the world

When you're traveling overseas in an unfamiliar country, and quite possibly using a different language, how can you make it easier to plan your route between house sits or travel adventures?

Over the past five years we've been helped by one of the best trip planner's we've come across, and one that is growing in popularity year on year.

Introducing trip planner Rome2rio

From the home screen of the Rome2rio route planning app, you simply enter your start and end locations, and let this easy to use travel planner search for a variety of different routes.

You'll be given plane, train, bus, ferry and car (self drive) options. Better still it allows for route planning with multiple stops.

If you log in, you can also save your trips for future viewing and there's also a web version if you don't have a smart phone or tablet.

Simple visual route planning options

I love just how simple it is to use at each step of the way. Once your route is displayed you can view each stage independently. Then you simply link through to the transport operator servicing that part of the journey.

There's an associated map that updates instantly each time you select an alternative route option. This makes it visually very easy to see which towns and cities your transport will pass through.

For planning an overall route, looking at transport alternatives and getting an idea of the cost involved, we haven't found anything better, easier or quicker. Now that we are in Europe considering inter-country travel, mainly by road, we think the Rome2Rio app will be an invaluable tool in our route assessment and planning.

Rome2rio Covid-10 travel updates

Each country search comes up with a handy reference to the current travel restrictions in place. This includes conditions of entry and Covid testing requirements, depending on where you are travelling from. It indicates what the local social distancing rules are AND gives the date on which the information was updated. A very useful tool in the current climate.

How up-to-date is the Rome2rio app?

There's one small criticism that seasoned travelers might have. Rome2rio appears to overlook the smaller "chicken bus" operators that don't always have their own websites.

For instance, on a route we know well from Bocas del Toro in Panama to San Jose, Costa Rica, part of the journey suggests an expensive $45 taxi ride. We know from experience that a local bus can be taken instead for just a couple of dollars.

The website states:

"Rome2rio searches a purpose built, unique repository of train, bus, plane, taxi, ferry, walking and driving routes. Our repository is constantly expanding as we add new data from sources around the world. Thousands of transport operators are represented in our database, making it the largest online repository of surface transport routes anywhere online."

So while the database is growing, we would suggest that you do some comparative research online if you want to be sure that you are getting the cheapest or most convenient deal.

Of course these smaller operators are likely to change their routes and prices without notice, as we've found ourselves, so it's understandable why these aren't always shown within the Rome2rio app. They tend to recommend the most reliable operators and routes, which is what most travelers prefer! We know not everyone wants to travel by "chicken bus" and would be quite satisfied with the options currently offered by this route planning app.

None of this should put you off giving this free route planning app a try.

Rome2rio claims to make travel planning easy, and it seems that many others are happy with the service offered. They have a trust score of 4.7 on Trust Pilot.

How does Rome2rio work in practice?

We used Rome2rio for our extensive trip planning over eight months in Mexico and Central America. We concluded that it was a great initial planning app. It showed us potential options for our trips to and from house sits, and on our between sits travel adventures.

By using Rome2rio we also came across Interjet, a local Mexican flight operator. We booked a couple of low cost domestic flights, and another equally cheap flight down to San Jose, in Costa Rica.

But, we still found ourselves complementing our research by checking out other travel apps. Some of those included:

Skyscanner for flights

The Man in Seat 61 for trains

GoogleMaps

Maps.Me

So we suggest initiating your route planning exercise with Rome2rio. However, don't necessarily rely on it as your only option. Check out local operators that might not be listed, and be open to using it conjunction with other apps.

All of that said, we would certainly suggest trying Rome2rio if you need to deal with any logistical challenges when traveling around the world, or between house sits.

And if you've arrived here wondering what on earth house sitting is... let us take you on our own voyage of discovery! We've been on the road now for almost a decade with the help of house sitting as an alternative vacation option - find out how you can stretch your travel budget and explore the world, slowly.
